Another excellent popular work on the foundations of physics by the author of The Elegant Universe, which I read a year ago. The earlier work was primarily an explanation of string theory; this book has more general background on general relativity and quantum theory, and only arrives at string theory and more recent developments about three fifths of the way through. The background was more than I really needed, but would be useful for someone beginning from scratch; it was a good clear introduction, and I did learn things from it. Green is particularly clear dealing with the specific interpretations of quantum theory, which are well laid out, and the Bell/Aspect experiments, and also gives a very good explanation of the Higgs field, which I had only a vague understanding of. The material on string theory is briefer than in the earlier book, which it refers to, but also a few years more up to date. One annoyance, which is also present in the first book but much more so here, is Greene's use of popular culture icons (the Simpsons, Mulder and Scully, etc.) in all his illustrations of various points. I could see this if there were analogies between the physics and aspects of these characters, but in most cases he might just as well have used A, B, C or common names, which would have been less distractingly cute.There was very little mathematics, which would have made some things clearer to me perhaps, but most of the math of quantum and string theory is beyond my knowledge anyway. I would recommend this to anyone with a general layperson's interest in physics.

If there is one subject I struggle with, it's the hard sciences. But Brian Greene's book is written exactly for people like me who probably haven't picked up a science book since high school and are mathmatically handicapped. And given the importance of the research going on, the discoveries so far, and the possibilities that are coming soon that may change our world in some really significant ways, it is also an important book.  In a nutshell, Greene delivers what we know and what we theorize about what, exactly, the reality of the universe is: what it is made out of, how it functions, and how it may have come about. Here are explanations of what "dimensions" are, why Higgs particles are the subject of furious exploration, and why huge supercolliders are being built. More to the point for the reader is that this book is great exercise for you imagination, trying to wrap your brain cells around concepts like braneworlds, "strings," and "dark matter."  These are concepts I run across rather frequently when I pick up a science fiction novel--this will definitely help my understanding of some of the high concepts there. But more exciting is the fact that the reality of this frontier of science is, in many ways, more fantastic and epic than fiction!

Author Brian Green is to be commended for his brilliant attempt to communicate the intricacies of particle physics, general and special relativity, the Big Bang, quantum mechanics and, yes--even string theory--to the interested lay person. It is a monumental effort ,since these topics are not easy for most people to grasp. I know because I have a genuine interest and have read numerous books purporting to make these theories understandable. This is the first one that I almost, nearly--at least sometimes almost nearly--got. And since the book contains an excellent glossary of terms I will at least now be able to sprinkle my conversation with some daunting verbiage--always a good thing.I did not find all the included graphics helpful, but a few were enormously helpful. I now have a much firmer grasp of what is meant by extra dimensions (never easy to visualize) and I was blown away by the thought that the universe probably resembles a Pringles potato chip, when I had always just assumed it must be balloon-like. Who would have thought.I think that if I read this book two or three more times, I might actually become an educated person. That’s unlikely, but at least there’s that great glossary.

Referencing Camus’ ultimate philosophical statement that the only question worth considering is suicide, Brian Green states at the beginning of this book that the ultimate question is really, “What is space?” and takes some 500+ pages to trace the chase for an answer. But he did an incredible job of discussing it, taking a hack like myself through the paces of Newtonian physics, Einstein’s theories of relativity, the bizarre world of quantum mechanics, and into string theory. This massive amount of astoundingly complex information was explained about as well as anyone has ever explained it to me (I've read several attempts), and with some levity. It took me over a year to read this, because I had to reread several sections several times, along with some time to let it seep into my head (to the extent possible) before moving on to the next section. And I plan to reread it again sometime in the future. It’s like a reference book.

I would be out of my depth if I even attempted a book review here. So no. Not doing that. It’s a fantastic read, goes without saying.Will share a few weird facts of the Cosmos as brought out in the book, though. The Universe is, to say the least, not what you think it is. It is a weird place. So we humans should feel right at home being here.#1 Weird Fact: Space and Time are not Immutable and UnchangeableLet’s start with the big things first. What is Space and Time? Isn’t it immutable and unchangeable? Isn’t Space and Time the grand arena, the unchanging permanent components of the Universe where stuff happens like galaxies colliding, supernovas, Earth going around the Sun, night becoming day etc?Isaac Newton thought so too.In his Principia Mathematica, Newton articulated a conception of Space and Time, declaring them absolute and immutable entities that provided the universe with a rigid, unchangeable arena. As far as Time was concerned, Newton even made the sweeping statement that he couldn’t be bothered trying to explain what Time is all about, as everyone knows what Time is. That is deep.But for Albert Einstein, Space and Time was not absolute and immutable. His insight into the very special nature of ‘light’ got him thinking on the nature of Space and Time.As a teenager, Einstein asked: What happens if you move at light speed?'What would a light wave look like if you were to chase after it at exactly light speed? Since you and the light wave would be zipping at exactly the same speed, you would be keeping perfect pace with the light. And so, the teenage Einstein concluded, from your perspective the light should appear as though it wasn’t moving. You should be able to reach out and grab a handful of motionless light just as you can scoop up a handful of newly fallen snow.'This fantastic theory sort of makes sense. But Einstein himself, in 1905, in his Theory of Special Relativity, postulated that the speed of light is a constant, no matter what the relative motion of the observer. So regardless of your state of motion, whether you chase a light beam, or run from it, or just stand still, the light retains its one fixed and never changing speed of about 3,00,000 Km per second.So Light will never appear stationary. No matter how fast you move.From this radical postulate that the speed of light is a constant, Einstein concluded that Space and Time are relative, not absolute and immutable as Newton assumed it to be. Each of us carries our own clock, our own monitor of the passage of time. Each clock is equally precise, yet when we move relative to one another, these clocks do not agree. They fall out of synchronization; they measure different amounts of elapsed time between two chosen events.This postulate of Einstein - that we all carry our ‘own clocks’, was proven by the famous Cesium Clock Experiment.'In 1971, Joseph Hafele and Richard Keating flew state-of-the-art Cesium-beam atomic clocks around the world on a commercial Pan Am jet. When they compared the clocks flown on the plane with identical clocks left stationary on the ground, they found that less time had elapsed on the moving clocks. The difference was tiny—a few hundred billionths of a second—but it was precisely in accord with Einstein’s discoveries.'So what it means is that when you move, Time travels more slowly for you than for someone who is stationary.The same is true of distance or Space. Each of us carries our own yardstick, our own monitor of distance in space. Each yardstick is equally precise, yet when we move relative to one another, these yardsticks do not agree; they measure different distances between the locations of two specified events.If Space and Time did not behave this way, the speed of light would not be a constant. Space and Time adjust themselves in an exactly compensating manner so that observations of light’s speed yield same result, regardless of the observer’s velocity.#2 Weird Fact: You are Moving at Light SpeedEinstein said that when you are stationary, you move at Light speed. At 3,00,000 Km per second. But through Time.In his theory of Special Relativity Einstein postulated the concept of ‘Movement through Time’.Consider this:We are used to the fact that objects can move through space.But Einstein said that there is another kind of motion that is equally important: objects also move through Time. Right now, the watch on your wrist and the clock on the wall are ticking away, showing that you and everything around you are relentlessly moving through time, relentlessly moving from one second to the next. Newton thought that motion through time was totally separate from motion through space-he thought these two kinds of motion had nothing to do with each other. But Einstein found that they are intimately linked. 'In fact, the revolutionary discovery of Special Relativity is this: When you look at something like a parked car, which from your viewpoint is stationary—not moving through space, that is—all of its motion is through time. The car, its driver, the street, you, your clothes are all moving through time in perfect sync: second followed by second, ticking away uniformly. But if the car speeds away, some of its motion through time is diverted into motion through space.'The speed of the car through Time slows down, when it diverts some of its motion through time into motion through Space. This means that the car’s progress through time slows down.And therefore time elapses more slowly for the moving car and its driver than it elapses for you and everything else that remains stationary.Special Relativity declares that the combined speed of any object’s motion through Space and its motion through Time is always precisely equal to the speed of light. The maximum speed through Space is reached when all light-speed motion through time is fully diverted into light-speed motion through space—one way of understanding why it is impossible to go through space at greater than light speed. Light, which always travels at light speed through space, is special in that it always achieves such total diversion. 'Time stops when travelling at the speed of light through space. A watch worn by a particle of light would not tick at all. Light realizes the dreams of Ponce de León and the cosmetics industry: it doesn’t age.'#3 Weird Fact: Space is Warped and CurvedWhy does the Earth go around the Sun? Or the moon around the Earth?It’s because Space is curved and warped. Not smooth and featureless as one might expect.If you roll a marble on a smooth wooden floor, it will travel in a straight line. But if you recently had a terrible flood and the floor dried with all sorts of bumps and warps, a rolling marble will no longer travel along the same path. It will be guided this way and that by the warps and curves on the floor’s surface. In 1915, in his Theory of General Relativity, Einstein postulated that the presence of matter or energy has an effect on Space much like the effect the flood had on the floor. Matter and energy, like the sun, cause Space to warp and curve.And just as a marble rolling on the warped floor travels along a curved path, Einstein stated that anything moving through warped space—such as the earth moving in the vicinity of the sun—will travel along a curved trajectory.That, according to Einstein, is how gravity exerts its influence amongst heavenly bodies and everything else in the Universe. #4 Weird Fact: The Quantum WorldIf you thought the Cosmos is kinda weird, then you probably have not been introduced to the Quantum world as yet. That’s where things get truly insane.Einstein classified Quantum mechanics in precise scientific terms: SpookyConsider a few bizarre facts predicted by quantum mechanics and scientifically proven:# Non LocalityQuantum mechanics predicts that interconnections between two particles need not be local. What this means is that something that happens here can be entwined with something that happens far away, even if nothing travels from here to that location far away. It’s called Entanglement.Quantum connection between two particles persists even if they are on the opposite sides of the Universe.For example, consider two people standing on opposite sides of a lake wearing sunglasses. Light from the surface of the lake reflects and photons are emitted. Quantum mechanics shows that there is a 50-50 chance that a particular photon reflected towards you from the surface of a lake will make it through your sun glasses.'When the photon hits the glass, it randomly “chooses” between reflecting back and passing through. The astounding thing is that such a photon can have a partner photon that has sped miles away in the opposite direction and yet, when confronted with the same 50-50 probability of passing through the sun glasses of the person standing on the opposite side of the lake, will somehow do whatever the initial photon does. Even though each outcome is determined randomly and even though the photons are far apart in space: if one photon passes through, so will the other.' This is the kind of nonlocality predicted by quantum mechanics.Quantum Mechanics says that two things can be separated by an enormous amount of space and yet not have a fully independent existence. A quantum connection can unite them, making the properties of each contingent on the properties of the other. # Probability wave of an electronAccording to quantum mechanics, every probability wave of an electron extends throughout all of space, throughout the entire universe. In many circumstances, though, a particle’s probability wave quickly drops very close to zero outside some small region, indicating the overwhelming likelihood that the particle is in that region. Nevertheless, so long as the probability wave of an electron somewhere in the Andromeda galaxy has a nonzero value, no matter how small, there is a tiny but genuine—nonzero—chance that the electron could be found there. So what it means is that there is a probability that the single electron you just exhaled sitting in your room can be found on the dark side of the moon.# Position and velocity of a particle Quantum mechanics claims that the position and the velocity of a particle cannot simultaneously have definite values. Instead, particles hover in quantum limbo, in a fuzzy, amorphous, probabilistic mixture of all possibilities; only when measured is one definite outcome selected from the many. #5 Weird Fact: Time is IllusoryThe passage of Time is illusory.The past, present and future have already happened.It’s like the movie reel. Each portion of the reel captures a particular scene. When you watch the movie, you have the illusion of various scenes playing out moment after moment. But that is just an illusion.Similarly, events in the entire Universe- past, present and future have already occurred. Or to put it differently, the past, present and future all exist simultaneously. What you experience as a flow of time is just an illusion. The Big Bang and the end of the Universe have all occurred and exist as frozen moments in time.We intuitively ascribe this particular moment, this ‘Now’ to be same for everyone across the Universe. For instance, if in this ‘Now’, am reading a book and someone is watching a movie in New York, and simultaneously a Volcano is erupting in Jupiter, we believe this ‘Now slice’ of Space-time should be the same for everybody.But this view is dated. A Newtonian way of envisioning reality. According to Newton’s absolute space and absolute time, everyone’s freeze-frame picture of the Universe at a given moment, contains exactly the same events; everyone’s ‘Now’ is the same ‘Now’, and so everyone’s ‘Now-list’ for a given moment is identical. If someone or something is on your ‘Now-list’ for a given moment, then it is necessarily also on my ‘Now-list’ for that moment. Most people’s intuition is still bound up with this way of thinking, but Special Relativity tells a very different story.As already explained, Time moves slower for someone in motion as compared to someone stationary.So there are ‘Different Now’s’ for the ones moving and those stationary. Their clocks will not match.Observers moving relative to each other have different conceptions of what exists at a given moment, and hence they have different conceptions of reality. At everyday speeds, the angle between two observers ’Now-slices’ is minuscule; that’s why in day-to-day life we never notice a discrepancy between our definition of ‘Now’ and anybody else’s.The author gives an example to drive this point home. A thought experiment:'Imagine that Chewie is on a planet in a galaxy far, far away—10 billion light-years from Earth—idly sitting in his living room. Imagine further that you and Chewie are not moving relative to each other. Since you are at rest relative to each other, you and Chewie agree fully on issues of space and time: you would slice up space-time in an identical manner, and so your ‘Now-lists’ would coincide exactly. After a little while, Chewie stands up and goes for a walk—a gentle, relaxing amble—in a direction that turns out to be directly away from you. This change in Chewie’s state of motion means that his conception of ‘Now’, his slicing up of space-time, will rotate slightly.This tiny angular change has no noticeable effect in Chewie’s vicinity: the difference between his new ‘Now’ and that of anyone still sitting in his living room is minuscule. But over the enormous distance of 10 billion light-years, this tiny shift in Chewie’s notion of ‘Now’ is amplified.His ‘Now’ and your ‘Now’, which were one and the same while he was sitting still, jump apart because of his modest motion. If Chewie walks away from you at about 10 miles per hour, the events on earth that belong on his new ‘Now-list’ are events that happened about 150 years ago, according to you! According to his conception of ‘Now’—a conception that is every bit as valid as yours and that up until a moment ago agreed fully with yours—you have not yet been born!If he moved towards you at the same speed, the angular shift would be opposite, so that his ‘Now’ would coincide with what you would call 150 years in the future! Now, according to his ‘Now’, you are no longer be a part of this world. And if, instead of just walking, Chewie hopped into the Millennium Falcon travelling at 1,000 miles per hour (less than the speed of a Concorde aircraft), his ‘Now’ would include events on Earth that from your perspective took place 15,000 years ago or 15,000 years in the future, depending on whether he flew away or towards you. So: if you buy the notion that reality consists of the things in your freeze-frame mental image right now, and if you agree that your ‘Now’ is no more valid than the ‘Now’ of someone located far away in space who can move freely, then reality encompasses all of the events in space-time.'If we can visualize ‘all of Space’ as really being out there, as really existing, we could also visualize ‘all of time’ as really being out there, as really existing, too. Past, present and future certainly appear to be distinct entities. But, as Einstein once said, “The distinction between past, present and future is only an illusion, however persistent.”The only thing that’s real is the whole of space-time.In this way of thinking, events, regardless of when they happen from any particular perspective, just are. They all exist. They eternally occupy their particular point in space-time. There is no flow. If you were having a great time at the stroke of midnight on New Year’s Eve, 1999, you still are, since that is just one immutable location in space-time.And the weirdness quotient of the Universe just increases when the author talks of Multi-verse, hidden dimensions, String Theory.....A great read.Can’t recommend this book enough.

This is my 31st book to read this year, the fourth on astro and particle physics, and by far the most fascinating. Though not as humorous or relatable a writer as Neil deGrasse Tyson, Brian Greene nevertheless tackles wide-ranging topics in particle physics and quantum mechanics, while also highlighting history from Greek astronomers to Newton to the advancements of modern day string/m-theorists and loop quantum gravity. This is a weighty tome, academic and verbose, but so very interesting in its subject matter. There are a number of terrific takeaways, like how microwave photons, traveling to us from 14 billion years ago, all emit nearly identical temperatures that fills out a pattern across the sky that's explained via jitters that arise from quantum uncertainty. Or how the farthest we can see of our observable universe is so minuscule that if we shrunk our entire universe to the size of Earth, what we can see with our most powerful telescopes represents but single grain of sand. Or how inflation cosmology, by mining gravity and in stark contrast to the standard Big Bang Theory in which the total mass energy of the universe was greater beyond words, could have produced all the matter and radiation in the universe by a speck of a uniform implaton field weighing a mere 20 pounds. I appreciate how well Greene explains the conflict between general relativity (which explains the macro: stars, galaxies, the expansion of the universe) and quantum mechanics (which explains the micro: atoms, quarks, strings) and specifically how their formulas break down when merged. A great example is a black hole, whose incredible gravitational pull is so immense it swallows everything beyond its event horizon (general relativity) before compressing all that ingested matter into a microscopic pinpoint (quantum mechanics). He explains the conundrum of how we cannot know the center of the black hole until we have a unifying theory. Special relativity has the constancy of the speed of light. General relativity has the equivalence principal. Quantum mechanics has the uncertainty principal. String theorists, meanwhile, continue to look for a unification of all forces in a quantum mechanical framework--a noble task indeed!This book is well worth your time. It was slow-going for me only because I had to reread (and sometimes triple read!) whole sections to better understand them, despite my familiarity from advanced physics and quantum mechanics courses in college. But I walked away with a keener appreciation of our universe, and the scientists tirelessly working at unmasking some of life's greatest mysteries.

The last part was ofcourse the awesome speculation that you can expect from Brian Greene, using the concepts he explained previously and making crazy speculations, presenting them in a very understandable and cool way. Awesome read for anyone interested in pop science books, but I would suggest it for some professionals aswell since there are mathematical equations laid out at the back of the book, in the notes. I found it pretty intriguing since I acctually understood some of those related to GR. Also this was not a light read so it took me awhile to get through it but it was so worht it.

Right off the bat I have to say that this audiobook was made twice as enjoyable as it would otherwise have been because of Michael Prichard. His voice, accent and cadence made me feel like I was listening to an old timey nineteen-fifties science radio show, and kept my attention from wandering as it sometimes tends to with audiobooks.The books in itself is lovely. I feel it provides a well written and quite accessible description of the general state of play in physics at the time it was written, through its use of pop-culture references has not aged very well in the interim. I also feel that some of the explanations could have been further elucidated with a good diagram or two (e.g. the endlessly convoluted “which path” quantum experiments with causality), but when I hunted down a print version of the book to check if there are any, and if there are whether they help, I was disappointed to discover the illustrations tiny and illegible, and hence adding little to no clarity.Now, to the serious down side. The reason I decided to go with Greene’s book is to try to understand what the deal is with superstring theory without getting too deeply enveloped in the maths of a theory I feel is very likely not the right answer (team LQG all the way!). The problem is that in this regard, the book remains quite “handwavy” with many of the explanations, and even at times refers the reader to Greene’s other book, The Elegant Universe, for an actual explanation or elaboration. Since roughly half of this rather hefty tome is, in fact, about superstring theory, this feels like a bit of a letdown. The presentation was nice and systematic, but the explanations left a lot to “just trust me on this one”.Oh, and string theory? Greene didn’t really convince me. I see where it comes from, but it seems to me as if to answer a simple problem – e.g. the fine-tuning of certain constants – string theorists have built an immensely complex, mathematically unintelligible and convoluted tower of assumptions and ideas that merely push the fundamental questions further down the line while at the same time opening a myriad new ones without answer.

What is it with theoretical physicists and their amazing ability to explain concepts through non-technical ordinary world analogies? Why can't writers from other fields (like experimental Physics, Chemistry and Biology) make things super interesting like this? This is evident in the abundance of physics books aimed at the general public. Is it because theoretical physics is all there is to it-- theoretical? Is it because theoretical physics is either an incessant succession of mathematical equations or highly complex experimental evidence, that they resort to explaining things like you're a five-year-old? And it actually works. I love how Prof. Brian Greene gives endless analogies, sometimes repetitive, to make sure that his message gets through his audience. He understands how intimidating the concepts can be. He avoids math entirely, but explains in a very detailed, patient way. I never thought I'd appreciate theoretical physics, even after watching 12 seasons of The Big Bang Theory. I only picked up this book because of the Netflix drama "Dark" and I just wanted to know more about time travel. But now, theoretical physics will be one of the subjects for my future reading lists, in addition to politics, finance, history and art. I cannot say that I fully understand everything now, despite the numerous thought experiments in the book. But the book piqued my interest enough that I'm watching YouTube videos about the subject every now and then. And of course, the book is dumbed down. It's meant for people with very little background of theoretical physics, so we could never expect one to be an expert after reading the book. And that's what makes it so great. It leaves you wanting for more. Still, it is not a quick read. It needs patience and an active mind from the reader. Otherwise, skimming through it will be a total waste of time. Looking forward to reading other books from Prof. Greene, Carl Sagan, Sean Carroll and Stephen Hawking in the future.Note: I'm a chemist. I work at the interface of chemistry, biology and medicine.

This book was published in 2004, so, yes - it's dated, but mainly in that some of the things that Brian hoped for have come to pass, like the discovery of gravitational waves by LIGO and the evidence to support the existence of the Higgs particle/field. Of course, any advances in the cutting edge research described that have been made since 2004 are not included. My biggest disappointment is that Brian doesn't have a support page for this book. In this book, Brian Greene gets down to the nuts and bolts of exactly what space and time are. He takes the reader through the history of the subject, and avoiding mathematical treatment at all costs, brings the reader to the state of the science as of 2004. He makes extensive use of analogies, but is careful to point out the limitations of the analogies he uses. The last 40% of the book or so, Brian gets more into the speculative views and cutting edge research into string/brane theory and even loop quantum gravity. He take the aside note several times to point out that experimental evidence is needed to bring these views and hypotheses into the mainstream of science, which is better than he did in his previous book. I think that maybe Neil got on his case about it. Anyhow, for its lack of mathematical treatment of the subject, the very abstract concepts are explained in great detail and Brian patiently hammers them home from multiple perspectives. Realizing that he is nearly beating a dead horse at times, he even advises readers who don't want to get that intimate with the subject to skim or even skip ahead, but he is faithful to his die-hard readers. You gotta love him for that! See the PBS/NOVA series and read this book as carefully or as casually as you like. I assure you that you will be educated, fascinated and mystified - in that order.

This was my favorite Brian Greene so far, even though I was a little late reading it...the existence of the Higgs boson has been verified and gravitational waves have been detected. I would have loved to have read Greene's interpretations and ideas in light of these recent discoveries (so I will look for a later book.) Brian Greene writes about a deep, complicated subject in an incredibly clarifying way. He clearly spends time thinking about what he wants to communicate and how, finally homing in on an insightful allegory or illustration to help the reader's understanding.The thing I like most about this book are the revelations about how very strange is the universe. Theories now point to our universe having at least 10 spacial dimensions (7 of them on such a small scale that they are undetectable). Nonetheless, there is a very good chance that evidence in support of these extra dimensions will be produced in the new super-colliders. Scientists have deduced the state of the universe 10^(-30) seconds or so after the big bang, finding evidence for a super-cooled field that drove a rapid inflationary period and then evolved into the Higg's field (responsible or particles having mass.) In fact, recent ideas suggest that space and time are "granular" (that is there is a limit to how finely they can be divided) and in fact that space it self may be constructed out of some yet to be detected fundamental building blocks. All through Greene's book is are the underlying questions: what IS space? what IS time? Why do these two things even exist? These are fundamental, intriguing questions; it is exciting to live in times when some of these questions might start to be answered.

“The Fabric of the Cosmos” is one of the more interesting and captivating books that I have ever read. Brian Greene is a physicist in his own right, but he is more or less the “narrator” as he follows the greatest minds in history as they attempted to define the universe at every levelBefore the end of the 19th century, some thought that, with the incorporation of electricity and magnetism, and with Newton in their back pocket, that physics had come to an end and all that was left was measurement (I actually remember this from engineering Physics almost 40 years ago!). But what Greene tells us is “buckle your seatbelts, you ain’t seen nothing yet.The book is not technical, it is qualitative. Even at that, there were some things that left me dizzy. At the first of the book it was pretty “simple,” first Newton, then Einstein and spacetime, then time itself and the flow of time, then on to entropy and gravity – the simple stuff. Then he starts making my head go around in circles with quantum mechanics, symmetry, cosmology, the shape of space, the Higgs field, on to string theory then superstring theory, and other dimensions.It is a hard book to summarize, because the subjects are so esoteric and seemingly at odds, but all at once making sense together.Brian Greene is a great writer. Again, as a “narrator,” he rarely inserts his viewpoint (which I’m sure is relevant), and lets the story flow. This is not a book to be digested in an afternoon, but one to be considered for the unfathomable complexities it covers.Finally, I would say that Greene and his colleagues and predecessors, belongs to a group of really super-smart people that makes us poor mortals realize what we really are.

Amazing book! Brief: Cosmology, the structure of the universe, general relativity, special relativity, quantum mechanics, entanglement, strings theory, time travelling, teletransportation, etc. at their best. I especially enjoyed the simple way Mr Greene makes such complex topics accessible to not versed in physics readers, like me! The most appreciated sections of the book for me were those dealing with Einstein's relativity, both general and special and how they relate to older and current cosmological theories and of course, their unification with quantum mechanics. Thanks to this book I realise I was missing very much information on these three fundamental theories; for instance, in regards to relativity, on how gravity depends not only on mass and energy but also on pressure, wow for that! The way Mr Greene deals with the quantum measurement problem is also fascinating; I had no idea (at all) of that. Entanglement and the explanation of why everything is not connected to everything were also mouth opening (as so many other things in this book). Unfortunately, I am sure, I arrived late to this party; the book is from 2004 and it even comes after his previous book and one of my next reads, "The Elegant Universe" (tell me about chaos! Haha...); I am certain many things have been added to these topics in the more than the twelve years that have gone by since Mr Greene wrote it, nevertheless, I learnt a lot.If you want to understand in about 30 or 35 hours of reading about the nature of the universe and therefore about ours, this is the book.

Brian Greene has done it again: make science easy and fun to understand. "The Fabric Of The Cosmos: Space, Time, And The Texture Of Reality" is a great work of non-fiction from its preface to its last page.The story goes this way: it tells the story of the universe from the beginning of times (if there was something like that) to the future (if there is something like this), stopping to explain different understandings of time (it goes by really fast) and space (which seems to vibrate a lot). We get cameos from Bart Simpson or Chewie and even a very cool DeLorean.Greene knows what he is doing. He is interested in making science interesting (he, he...) and he knows how to do it. The examples are clear, the science simplified but not simple, and his writing style is engaging and enjoyable, never becoming too technical, and always fun. It falls sometimes into repetition ('the mathematical inclined reader' just too cringeworthy after its umpteenth appearance) and sometimes it all sounds a little mumblejumble (reader's fault), but it never becomes boring. Only the last third, with string theory, supersymmetry and similar it may become a little bit too head-scratching.The other minor quibble is that some of the ground (or quite a lot, depending on your views) was already tread in his previous work, "The Elegant Universe". But with a subject as interesting as this, you won't mind.7.5/10(Original English Version)

3.5*s“Fabric Of the Cosmos” is a popular science non fiction novel that chronologically relates all major scientific discovery’s in physical discourse to how they help better our understanding of “space time and the texture of reality”. The book is split rather conveniently into all discoveries pertaining to the concept of space (general relativity, Newtonian mechanics), then time (Boltzmann concept of entropy, arrow of time), and finally the fabric of the cosmos (string/M theory, higher dimensions, time travel, quantum mechanics). The book is well structured, and easily understood, a laudable feat especially considering that it attempts to explain physical concepts while still maintaining a certain paucity of mathematical formulae. Now a complaint I have about the book is that certain concepts were not entry level and required prior knowledge on the readers part. I felt while reading that had I not known about this particular topic from previous curiosity driven escapades, I would have a hard time understanding what was being taught. The portion on relativity was poorly explained, and other portions (quantum mechanics) were not fully delved into, atleast not to a point where a greater understanding could have been ascertained. Other than that, it was a solid book, one that I would not re-read in its entirety, but I would go back to sections that caught my interest. Also: Big Bang theory season 4 episode 20

This book is a tricky one to review... I appreciated the compilation of modern physics topics (no matter how scattered or loosely related) and compared to many other popular physics books this one discusses more superstring theory and touches on M theory which is nice. However the amount of times I rolled my eyes reading Simpsons or X-Files metaphors to describe the multiverse was unnecessary, especially since many times the metaphors were flawed. (for example the bowl metaphor for the Higgs field zero value). I also didn’t love how Greene would pose a question and then deliver multiple answers- I would prefer to have it structured initially as a listing of the different proposals so you aren’t filling in the gaps prematurely, and then maybe discussing after. The organization and recall when reading could have been improved with a table of proposals under each theory or at least with bolded words- even when I was well versed in a topic it was hard to keep track of what he was talking about simply from lack of structure. It’s also important to note that this book was written right before the Large Hadron Collider opened so several suggestions regarding residue energy from Higgs collisions is outdated. Still really like this book though, and it reminded me of several topics that I’d like to continue researching!

I was fascinated by the examples and analogies used to illustrate the ideas. For example, the travel along a northern and a northeastern axis is great to illustrate travel along the time and space dimension. Unfortunately, the writer tended to be too repetitive or elaborate. Sometimes, too many pages were spent in describing a simple idea. I am sure most readers will get the idea of non-locality or entanglement with just 25% of the text. The lead-up to the idea that entropy was very low at the creation of the universe and therefore has been increasing was simply excessive, giving the impression that the writer is engaging in page-fillers like a poor fiction author. The writer also seemed to think that repetitions will clarify a complex idea. This gets very tiresome and energy sapping after a while. Much as I love to follow all the concepts and finish the book, I found myself skipping entire chapters. Then at chapter 14 in the section on Reality and Imagination, you find that old tiresome discussion on Einstein, Mach and the spinning bucket once again. What is the point here? Ultimately, I could not bother to finish the book. Quite disappointing.

Others have written reviews far more articulate than I could manage. Pros: - (somewhat) accessible for laypeople- Some good analogies- Well-structuredCons: - Inaccessible in many spots- Some terrible analogies (unless you watch the Simpsons. I don't)- Uneven in the amount of depth with which each topic is explored. Some concepts get a simple "it's that way because of math" while others get an entire proof lasting dozens of pages.I came away understanding the possibility of multiple dimensions, entanglement, and time's arrow, which was all I could have expected. I was frustrated with Green's treatment of entropy. Really? it's more probabilistic for the entire universe to have jumped into existence at this very moment, including the ordering of thoughts and memories in my mind, than for us to have arrived at this moment naturally, and yet "we choose" to accept a natural occurrence anyway? I have a problem with this.

A comprehensive book outlining the important developments in theoretical physics in a logical and somewhat inspiring way. The book is perfect for a layman who wants to really familiarize him/herself on important concepts in the realm of theoretical physics and avoid the "pop-sciency" side of say, articles on the Internet or explanation videos on you tube. The author reserves mathematical/technical jargon and uses highly visual metaphors to describe these physics concepts. In addition, the author tends to reserve his opinions and does his best to focus much more of the book on experimentally proven concepts.Overall, it's a perfect book for a hobbyist like me. I gave it four stars only because it skimmed through some details I thought were rather important to explain. Highly recommended. Also, if you are new to the subject matter, the book is not intended as a fast read. You will need to take breaks and mull over the concepts presented here.

To the review inclined reader, I'd like to say (like many other reviewers to this book have) that this is no easy read. Quite far from the basic aspects shown in Sagan's books, this feels like a nice bridge between science communication and an actual science book, meaning it goes further in depth on the scientific concepts shown, but there are still a lot of analogies to ease things up (and an awful lot of those are used with Simpsons' character). Some parts are quite a headache, but I'd say that's much more to blame on the difficulty of grabbing such complex concepts rather than Greene's skill in presenting them to the reader. The only thing thing that feels tiresome it's the excess of examples that Greene quotes. There are always three of them, and he is always reaffirming what he's shown. Sometimes it's pretty helpful, but also tiresome. All in all, it's was a worthful read. I have a different view of string theory, and it's clearer how works in Cosmology can be achieved.

I followed the Elegant Universe by diving straight into this (and have the Hidden Reality to come next). I enjoyed this one more than the Elegant Universe. The first book laid so much groundwork that this book built upon, that it felt far less technical and dense to get to the heart of the matter. It also feels more philosophical which appeals to me. I like the science but there’s something to be said about the Why? and not just the How?Brian Greene’s examples and de-jargon-ifying (definitely a word, look it up) is on point as ever. I love the George and Gracie references of the Elegant Universe (I assume he’s going with George Burns, “say good night, Gracie” was a references), and the Simpsons allusions of the Fabric of the Cosmos is even better, pop culturally speaking. It makes it fun, accessible. But the explanations are really good, regardless of how entertaining they are in general.

I find I do better with the Brian Greene books in the audio versions. It is like being back at a college lecture - one that is 22 hours long, but one that I actually want to attend. But the content is great. This is actually my second reading of this book. With the successes reported by LIGO this year, it sparked my interest to tackle this one again.Despite the author making the content as straight-forward as possible, I do think some will struggle. A math and science background will help here somewhat, but I think unless you were focused on physics or physical chemistry you will still have some gaps in your background for reading this book. You may have to re-read a passage or two for better understanding or maybe (gosh!) look up something on your own. But I think most people can get through it, and it will open your eyes to how strange our universe really is.

I was always interested in physics, and was disappointed when my high school physics more or less ignored modern physics and left me hanging.This book explains what our high school education left out. From the parts where we memorized Newton's laws without ever asking: "So, if every motion is relative, what is the acceleration in the second law relative to?"; to relativity, quantum physics, cosmology and string theory. Brian Green lets his enthusiasm about physics come out in every line and involve you. The book is written in a simple yet captivating way. Anyone, with almost no understanding of mathematics can understand it easily. And it helps you gain insight into physic's fundamental theories.I recommend it to all the physics enthusiast out there who have lost hope on finding a text that is not a work of fictional-popular-pseudoscience, and yet not too technical to understand.

to be fair this is meant to be a book for those without knowledge and to some extent the author tries to relate to to the here and now, However, the copious pages of notes, many of which are detailed whilst others merely cite publications, counter its general public accessibility. Not only are there notes at the end of the book but there are asterisked parts within the book WHAT? WHAT?????????, Greene tries to relate to to the modern day but as someone who has never watched the Simpsosns or Mulder and Scully he really doesn't achieve that aim. AMOST of all i am sincerely sick of his note "for the mathematically minded" this book is meant to be for ALL not just the mathematically minded. Having said all that there were many parts that I eventually understood in the moment of time and dimension that i read in. Unfortunately they will not travel across time with me.

This book is essentially a story of our understanding of the cosmos, right from Newton to the early 21st century, ending with a description of where contemporary physics stands. It is very non-mathematical (relying heavily on analogies), while packing serious content. The ideas discussed are complex (obviously!), and the author has taken genuine efforts in explaining them to a layman, while not "dumbing them down". Given all this, I have to acknowledge that I still found it a challenging read. I got stuck at places, had to re-read previous topics, finally taking about two months to finish the book. However, it was an AMAZING read, well worth the effort. The ideas discussed are simply fascinating (my favorite- the delayed choice experiments). The book is heavy, and my only regret is that there is only so much that I can retain. Highly recommended!!

Excellent summary of how our understanding of cosmos evolved from Newton till modern day String Theory. The author gives excellent analogies to all the concepts wherever possible. The book increases your curiosity in physics and gives a basic understanding of all complex concepts to a non science person almost without any mathematics! Green's strength lies in conveying complex ideas in a easy way with the right kind of analogies which speaks volumes of his capabilities. One thing I got a great explanation that I didn't find elsewhere is on the Spooky Action at a distance or the EPR paradox.  A little biased towards String theory though it is understandable given the author is himself a string theorist. It is almost like he is trying to convince a layman that String Theory is the one most probably going to unite general relativity and quantum mechanics.

What a project this book was. I would say a couple other physic books should be read prior to this one. It was a little harder than I thought it would be. Something I did love about the author is when he gave us permission to skim through certain sections. I liked reading his perspective, and it was a cool feeling reading about the Higgs particle, knowing now, it has been found and proven. Everything is so small, it gives off an eerie feeling. Brian throws questions out that will turn your mind upside down. Have you ever questioned what “now” means? Is the now, now, or is it now, and now isn’t really now, because we have to take into consideration the delay of our brain to process and interpret the stimuli of now. So is now just an illusion, and a collection of all the memories of other nows? This gives a whole new meaning to mindfulness? So we are trying to understand the world through the window of our brains. We like to look at science as the know all. We have found rules the universe seems to follow, but they will always only be seen through our eyes. Even our eyes absorbing photons affects the results of experiments! The act of observing the experiment changes the results. So can we ever know true reality? Now after learning about entanglement, decoherence, and quantum eraser, the term spookiness at a distance becomes even more meaningful. If two photons become entangled, they will forever be “one”, even if separated by depths of galaxies. Brian tries to find explanations for how this could be possible. Is there a communication well beyond the speed of light? Or are the two photons really one? The level of interconnectedness is bizarre. Einstein found he could do something here, and it can have effects there. How far can you bring this to life in the macro world? The book even mentions black holes can become entangled. Us bigger levels are made up of these quantum small levels. We are living and made up of a world of quantum weirdness. The space that exist between the atoms making up our bodies is mind bending. What makes everything so orderly and separate? Brian talks about entropy, and he uses it as a base to explain the arrow of time, being that entropy is the law saying more order moves towards less order. As the mysteries unravel, think of how the photons, these tiny minute dots have such crazy entanglements, and then think of us humans, tiny dots in the grand scheme of the universe. Are we not capable of crazy “spookiness at a distance”? The universe is expanding at such a high rate(faster than the speed of light) that by the time light reaches us from 14 billion light years away, we will be long gone. Our galaxy will have expanded into nothing. But, what is nothing? Trying to decipher the emptiness we think is vast and nothing, but we find it is actually full of what is called dark matter. Basically this is just a term for something we can’t put a real identity on. The gist is after calculating all the mass inside most of the galaxies, scientist found there isn’t enough matter for gravity to keep the galaxies from spreading out and absorbing into each other. There has to be something giving the galaxies more matter for gravity to do its thing and have individual galaxies rather than one giant galaxy universe. The matter inside the galaxy is what pulls everything in. This matter is called dark matter, they seem to know it exist but they can’t quite get their finger on it. It actually contributes to a significant amount of matter in the universe as well as dark energy which takes up about 70% of the universe. It's the darkness that keeps us together! Dark energy is the energy creating the expansion of the universe. Greene talks a lot about repulsion from gravity as part of the source for the expansion of the universe also but dark energy is another thing they are blaming universal inflation on. It is confusing. Another special something that takes up “nothingness” is the Higgs particle. The higgs particle now known and proven to be a reality exist as a cosmic higgs ocean. The higgs particle gives all matter its mass by the way it interacts with the components it is made of. The more drag the higgs particle gives an electron or quark the heavier it will be. The top quark is the heaviest quark and has the most drag. A photon who has no mass will speed through space at the speed of light because it doesn’t interact and get slowed down by the higgs particle. Quarks on the other hand which make up the elementary particles of matter do interact. Greene- “ A more precise picture is to think of the molasses like drag force of the Higgs ocean as giving mass to fundamental particles such as the electrons and quarks”. Experiments have proven this to be true by releasing I beleive electrons at a high speed and with a freaking bad ass microscope actually seeing the higgs run into the particle released. Super fascinating stuff if you ask me. He talks a lot about the string theory also. Here is a quick quote,”The different vibrational patterns in string theory correspond to different kinds of particles”. E=mc squared which says energy equals mass. So the energy of the vibration of the string creates the particle and its mass. So the lighter particle will be more placid strings. The universe is a symphony of vibrating strings? I am lost. At this point physics becomes more of a philosophy. Which is probably why I love it, even though,I don’t really understand it. Greene ends the book saying,” Looking for familiar spacetime in the deepest laws of nature may be like trying to take in Beethoven's ninth Symphony solely note by single note”. Ah, to me, this means the universe isn’t only beautiful, it is more beautiful than I will ever know.

In this book Brian Greene embarks on an explanation of the universe through the eyes of Physics, and it's a wonderful journey.From the reasoning of Sir Isaac Newton and Albert Einstein to recent discoveries and theories, the books presents us with the logic behind all of the well-know theories, and this is by far one of the most important and relevant aspects of it. Being able to see into the minds of our most prominent scientists and how they thought and discovered things that most of us are almost incapable of grasping is humbling but also inspiring.This is not by a very far stretch a light read, but if you manage to get half way through (beyond Newton's bucket experiment) you absolutely won't regret it.

Excellent, a good, basic, outline of Superstring theory and a basic guide to the rudiments of the terminology used in this physics debate. Brian Greene (the author)used some common characters from various (2) popular television programs to illustrate these particular points, and even I who didn't necessarily follow these programs were able to see the relevance of the use. It is a good introductory discussion on the themes involved in this debate ,about,the place played in the theory of reality, concentrating on an understanding of the direction of "Time"within the theory. Overall I would say that it is a good book for the parameter cosmologist to read, I am not sure how good it would be for anyone with a background knowledge in the field.

An outstanding workIn some respects this book is an extension (and a substantial one) of physicist Brian Greene's well-received The Elegant Universe: Superstrings, Hidden Dimensions, and the Quest for the Ultimate Theory (1999) in which he attempted the very difficult task of explaining relativity, quantum mechanics, and string theory to the educated layperson while keeping the mathematics in footnotes. Here he covers some of the same ground as he patiently and painstakingly illuminates some of the most important ideas in physics and cosmology, employing new ways to explain the nearly unexplainable.His watchword is "reality" and his overarching idea is that reality is not as we intuitively think it is. (p. 5) This is one of the startling revelations from relativity and the quantum world: namely that our perceptions and concepts built up through evolutionary experience are NOT adequate to understand the world of the very small or the very large. The dual nature of the particle/wave is the most obvious example, and one that Greene examines at length. We have no way of intuitively appreciating the fact that elementary particles are not just particles but waves as well--actually probability waves. But there is also our notion of something and "nothing" that is being tested by modern physics. What appears to be empty space is in fact far from empty. Moreover, space itself has unsuspected qualities, as Greene demonstrates in his discussion of the postulated Higgs fields.Particularly exciting was the way Greene makes inflation credible ("the universe could easily have expanded by a factor of 10 to the 30th, 10 to the 50th or 10 to the 100th or more" within a time frame "as short as ten to the minus 35th seconds" p. 284) by positing that before the Higgs field made its phase transition, all quanta had zero mass. It doesn't take much energy to move something with zero mass. (Or maybe something with zero mass can't be moved at all.) At any rate, very shortly after the big bang, space and presumably time, expanded enormously (faster than the speed of light, actually--but, as Greene, assures us, the speed limit on light does not apply to expanding space).In short what Greene does in this book is take the reader to the edge of what can be understood. What he writes is exciting and awe-inspiring, and he writes so very well, and he works so hard at trying to reach every reader. However you'll forgive me if I get some of this wrong. And of course I am compelled to point out (as Greene does himself) that the Higgs field and therefore inflation, not to mention string theory and M-theory, etc., remain as yet in the category of the not proven.Obvious is Greene's faith in the "beauty" of mathematics to point the way to physical truth. He recalls the work of Glashow, Weinberg and Salam in predicting the existence of W and Z particles because of the "strong faith these physicists had in the power of theory and the beauty of symmetry that gave them the confidence to go forward." (p. 266) Whether the beauty that physicists see in the equations for string theory, etc., will lead them to a deeper understanding of the cosmos remains to be seen. Most readers are familiar with what one ugly fact can do to a beautiful theory.One of the most enjoyable parts of the book is Greene's delineation of time and time's "arrow." I have always been fascinated with time and have spent many hours trying to figure out what it is. Reading between the lines, it would appear that Greene believes that events create time. Or more precisely, that asymmetry creates time. He writes "If the universe had perfect temporal symmetry--if it were completely unchanging--it would be hard to define what time even means." (p. 228) Of course this is somewhat circular, but I think I can add that if the universe were completely empty, it would also "be hard to define" what time means.On the question of "Does time have a direction?" Greene writes that "the laws of physics...show a complete symmetry between past and future." (pp. 144-145) Yet, in everyday life, time is always aimed toward the future. An egg splatters. It doesn't unsplatter. Why is that? Greene brings entropy into the picture, noting that entropy has increased since the big bang. He explains that the unsplattered egg has a very low degree of entropy (that is, it is highly ordered, thanks to DNA, energy from the sun, etc.). Eggs splatter more easily than they could ever hope to unsplatter because there are an uncounted number of ways that the egg can have high entropy (ways it can be splattered about) but only one (or very few) ways it can be pristine. In a footnote on page 511 Greene articulates something that I have been waiting to hear from a prominent physicist. Suppose the universe began to contract, seemingly reversing time's arrow. Would eggs unsplatter? Greene's answer: "Physical processes (eggs breaking, people aging, and so on) would still happen in the usual direction..."What impressed me the most about this book is just how well produced it is. Greene improves on his previous opus in two important ways. His explanations are more detailed and more accessible to the average reader; and his information and understanding are more up to date. Furthermore, the book is beautifully presented with many drawings, a glossary, selected readings for further study, and a fine index. There are 493 pages of text and 43 pages of notes. It is handsomely presented and beautifully edited and proofread. This is a book clearly worth the money and then some. --Dennis Littrell, author of “The World Is Not as We Think It Is”

If you’re curious about the universe, if you always had a hankering to understand relativity, quantum mechanics, string theory, M-theory, and how many supersymmetric particles can dance on the head of a pin, one of the ways to make a little progress on your never-ending journey of understanding reality is to read Brian Greene’s The Fabric of the Cosmos: Space, Time, and the Texture of Reality.He begins with a spinning bucket of water to illustrate the notions of motion held by Newton, Leibniz, Ernst Mach, and Einstein in their conflicting views of absolute versus relative space. For a couple of chapters and most of a hundred pages he threads the ideas of those thinkers through that simple spinning bucket and concludes unsurprisingly that Einstein has the best handle on the issue with his general relativity theory supporting a surprisingly absolute concept of spacetime and accelerated motion. And Greene manages this while not putting you to sleep, keeping you entertained with intuitive analogs and earthy examples such as a pistol duel between two whimsically named characters, Itchy and Scratchy.Although my educational background is physics (from a long time ago), I learned something new—an astounding revelation for me in a chapter devoted to quantum theory. To the counter-expectations of Einstein and many others, physics (aka nature and reality) was proven to be non-local as a result of experiments in the 1970s and 1980s based on an insight by physicist John Bell in 1964. This earth-shaking result, violating the cherished notion of the locality of physics, establishes that things can be interconnected instantaneously at a distance, sinking Einstein’s notions of hidden variables and the incompleteness of quantum mechanics. The experimental establishment of quantum entanglement and the discovery that it apparently disobeys the law—the speed limit of light—nearly brought down the Special Theory of Relativity, leaving it in a delicate and unsteady balance with quantum theory.The book progresses through three more broad themes—“Time and Experience,” “Spacetime and Cosmology,” “Origins and Unification”—before concluding with a final “Reality and Imagination.” The topics within those themes include the ebb and flow of time and its dance with entropy (which way does time’s arrow point?), the teeming fullness of the cosmic vacuum, the Higgs field and the Big Bang, repulsive gravity, inflation and a runaway universe, string theory and M-theory, and curled-up six-dimensional Calabi-Yau shapes in ten-dimensional spacetime.As might be expected, the last theme, “Reality and Imagination,” is full of blue sky (or should that be black sky?) conjectures on dark matter, dark energy, and the fate of the universe among other things, but among those other things is discussed the concrete and tantalizing possibility that strings (the fundamental constituents of string theory whose different vibrational modes constitute everything we’re made of) might be much larger than previously thought, which would translate into the CERN Large Hadron Collider finding scads and scads of previously unseen supersymmetric particles, like ”a well-hit golf ball ricocheting around the inside of a piano.” The book was written in 2004, and since then the first phase of collider operations has concluded with the discovery of the Higgs particle but not much else. Although this is not a refutation of string theory, it puts a damper on some aspects of it that Greene waxes enthusiastically about. There remains a chance that the future upgraded version of the collider will find something in its extended energy range.This book manages to make an entertaining story out of an incredibly esoteric and still unsettled field. Greene is a master of the simple and easily grasped analogy, which is why his explanations are so easy to follow and understand. He more than acknowledges the incompleteness of our knowledge of the cosmos, and in fact revels in its incompleteness as an exciting path forward through a jungle of unknowns, a never-ending path of adventure for the human spirit. If you’re curious about the cosmos and the meaning of space and time, then The Fabric of the Cosmos is your book. It does a damn good job of laying out some of the answers and being entertaining as well, but leaves plenty more unknowns to ponder ...But then that’s the nature of the infinite journey we’re on, isn’t it?

Very cool overview of the state of physics and the cosmos to date. In depth, but still quite readable.---------Amazon.comAs a boy, Brian Greene read Albert Camus' The Myth of Sisyphus and was transformed. Camus, in Greene's paraphrase, insisted that the hero triumphs "by relinquishing everything beyond immediate experience." After wrestling with this idea, however, Greene rejected Camus and realized that his true idols were physicists; scientists who struggled "to assess life and to experience the universe at all possible levels, not just those that happened to be accessible to our frail human senses." His driving question in The Fabric of the Cosmos, then, is fundamental: "What is reality?" Over sixteen chapters, he traces the evolving human understanding of the substrate of the universe, from classical physics to ten-dimensional M-Theory.Assuming an audience of non-specialists, Greene has set himself a daunting task: to explain non-intuitive, mathematical concepts like String Theory, the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle, and Inflationary Cosmology with analogies drawn from common experience. For the most part, he succeeds. His language reflects a deep passion for science and a gift for translating concepts into poetic images. When explaining, for example, the inability to see the higher dimensions inherent in string theory, Greene writes: "We don't see them because of the way we see…like an ant walking along a lily pad…we could be floating within a grand, expansive, higher-dimensional space."For Greene, Rhodes Scholar and professor of physics and mathematics at Columbia University, speculative science is not always as thorough and successful. His discussion of teleportation, for example, introduces and then quickly tables a valuable philosophical probing of identity. The paradoxes of time travel, however, are treated with greater depth, and his vision of life in a three-brane universe is compelling and--to use his description for quantum reality--"weird."In the final pages Greene turns from science fiction back to the fringes of science fact, and he returns with rigor to frame discoveries likely to be made in the coming decades. "We are, most definitely, still wandering in the jungle," he concludes. Thanks to Greene, though, some of the underbrush has been cleared. --Patrick O'KelleyFrom Publishers WeeklyString theory is a recent development in physics that, by positing that all which exists is composed of infinitesimally small vibrating loops of energy, seeks to unify Einstein's theories and those of quantum mechanics into a so-called "theory of everything." In 1999, Greene, one of the world's leading physicists, published The Elegant Universe (Norton), a popular presentation of string theory that became a major bestseller and, last fall, a highly rated PBS/Nova series. The strength of the book resided in Greene's unparalleled (among contemporary science writers) ability to translate higher mathematics (the language of physics) and its findings into everyday language and images, through adept use of metaphor and analogy, and crisp, witty prose. The same virtues adhere to this new book, which offers a lively view of human understanding of space and time, an understanding of which string theory is an as-yet unproven advance. To do this, Greene takes a roughly chronological approach, beginning with Newton, moving through Einstein and quantum physics, and on to string theory and its hypotheses (that there are 11 dimensions, ten of space and one of time; that there may be an abundance of parallel universes; that time travel may be possible, and so on) and imminent experiments that may test some of its tenets. None of this is easy reading, mostly because the concepts are tough to grasp and Greene never seems to compromise on accuracy. Eighty-five line drawings ease the task, however, as does Greene's felicitous narration; most importantly, though, Greene not only makes concepts clear but explains why they matter. He opens the book with a discussion of Camus's The Myth of Sisyphus, setting a humanistic tone that he sustains throughout. This is popular science writing of the highest order, with copious endnotes that, unlike the text, include some math.

The book The Fabric of the Cosmos by Brian Greene is a book that is very informative but is still intriguing. I like how the book showed that optimism is key, which I can relate to because I made my entire photo essay on optimism. The book takes you through the history of physics, all the way from Newton up to String theory. The book will make you realize what you thought was the truth, is actually just an illusion. I had a great time reading this book and I also feel it also enhanced my knowledge in the world of physics. In the Novel the author makes an apparent argument that just because something (theories, equations, etc.) get triumphed by new and more accurate things doesn’t mean that the original thing is wrong or that we should that person any less credit for coming up with it. “Newton’s theory of gravity has been superseded by Einstein's theory of General Relativity, but it would be naïve to say that Newton’s theory was wrong.” In this quote the author couldn’t have been more direct in making his argument. He shouted, “give Newton his credit”, and it made me think. What I realized he was saying was that we are too focused on things that are brand new, we forget that without the person who started it all, no one would be able to make more advanced versions of that thing or idea. I feel like this goes for everything, not just physics. We need to appreciate those who made the original product were just as--if not more-- important than those who built apon it. One main conflict in the novel is that General Relativity and quantum physics don’t match up. Since general relativity is about things as big as stars and galaxies and quantum physics is things that are extremely small, you’d think that they wouldn’t need to mix. And you’re right, except for the big bang, when things are really small, are also really massive. “This requires a theory that would have to overcome perhaps the greatest obstacle theoretical physics has faced in the past 80 years: a fundamental rift between General Relativity and quantum physics.” As you can see this is obviously a giant problem, two of the most widely accepted theories in physics come up with complete non-sense when they are put together. To resolve this conflict the author talks about Superstring and M theory which (in their simplest forms) add spacial dimensions to the universe so that General Relativity and quantum physics come together. I find string/M theory very interesting, but trying to imagine more spatial dimensions is next to impossible. That is why I feel that as physics, we should keep our minds open and work hard to try and solve the problem of unifying General Relativity and quantum physics. The big picture or theme the author has is that in physics, once you think you finished one problem(or anything), you've opened the door to so many other ones. He shows this in multiple ways. One is “With this stunning realization, Einstein’s general relativity exposed a loophole in the more than two-hundred-year-old belief that gravity is always an attractive force . . . when pressure is negative, there is a contribution to gravity that would have shocked Newton. It’s repulsive.” This is a prime example that figuring out one things, just opens up a whole new world of unknown things. Einstein figured out his theory of General Relativity, which in turn helped us gain key information into the Big Bang. I feel that this theme is important in the field of physics because without it we would probably would have felt we understood everything, which is far from the truth. I feel that the lessons learned in this book can help you to live life with a greater appreciation of people who invented or made the original, and it can help you live with more optimism that there is always something bigger and better. As I have shown, this book taught me a lot about physics but it also helped me live my life better than I did before. Not to mention this book was extremely interesting and made me not want to put it down the whole time. All in all, if you want to learn about physics or just want to read an extremely interesting book, then I suggest you pick this book up.

My investigation into physics and where the universe came from continues. In this book, Brian Greene gives us a history of science from Newton and classical physics, through the special and general theories of relativity, quantum mechanics and ever onward into string theory, branes and beyond. By the end you're getting into the realms of fantasy - by which I mean theories for which no experimental evidence has yet been found - but it is all fascinating and presented with as little recourse to maths as possible. Which is useful because I wouldn't understand that. Not understanding that, you of course have to take Greene's word for it at times because there's no way for you to verify the workings and conclusions. You just have to trust that professional physicists haven't missed anything, or made any mistakes, or form part of an evil club that wants us all to believe some over-complicated, made up shit for their own nefarious ends. Thankfully there is enough that makes sense, and that has been proven experimentally for me to have faith in what I'm reading. What could their nefarious aims be anyway? Wasting millions of pounds on particle accelerators, continuing to write on blackboards and wearing brown at every available opportunity?So Greene is able to describe [most of] these discoveries and theories in purely conceptual ways, which means mathematical dunces like me can comprehend it. Some credit for that might go to the fact that I've read about some of this stuff before, so it may be sinking in, but it is getting clearer and this probably is the clearest description - particularly of quantum mechanics - that I've come across so far. I think back to Brian Cox's "The Quantum Universe", and apart from the slit experiment, I can't even remember what else he filled the book with. It was almost incomprehensible, and full of all this stuff about winding clocks. None of that here. Cox's method reminded me of when you have a shit maths teacher (as I invariably did at school), and they'd show you an unfathomable method for doing a calculation. Then you'd go home and ask your older, more mathematical sister (by which I mean 'good at maths' rather than 'constructed out of numbers and symbols' any more than the rest of us) to help with your homework, and she'd go, "what are you doing it like that for? Do it like this..." and then show you a really easy method that makes you wonder whether the teachers are doing it on purpose. I suppose the aims of these books were different - Cox probably wanted to show off the fancy maths so we don't just think he's a ponce off the telly.I enjoyed reading this - particularly the part where I got to look intelligent, reading it on the train - though I have to agree with other reviewers that using characters from popular culture in examples was... annoying, for lack of a better word. The main gripe though, is that, being published in 2004 or 2005, it's more than a decade out of date, so I had to look up some things on Wikipedia to see if there had been any breakthroughs since. The Big Hadron Collider (sic - I'm not an imbecile) was still under construction at the time, so when Greene hints at what it might be able to tell us, you want to know whether that turned out to be the case. I can't see that the LHC has found definitive proof of the Higgs Boson, but it does seem at least that the existence of gravity waves have been confirmed by LIGO. So that's quite exciting, and it isn't really the book's fault that it's 10 years old anyway. If you're after a comprehensive but accessible introduction to cosmology, I can heartily recommend this. Should I give it 5 stars? Hard to say... it's hard to give anything 5 stars. Could this book have been any better? In all fairness, probably not much. Go on then, I will.
