In this beautifully written book, string theorist Brian Greene takes on the enormously difficult task of explaining the puzzling and complex world of modern-day theoretical physics in language aimed at the common reader, and succeeds brilliantly.Beginning with a simple articulation of space as fixed and absolute in the Newtonian model, Greene uses easy-to-grasp analogies to progress to Einstein's conception of relativity and spacetime, and how gravity in essence represents the warping and curving of the spacetime fabric. He motivates arguments that most of us take for granted without ever questioning - why does time always flow only in one direction as we perceive it, when all physical laws are time-symmetric, and are valid forwards or backwards? Why for example, asks Greene, do we see an egg roll off the kitchen counter and splatter into many pieces, but never do we see this process work in reverse - splattered egg shells on the ground assemble into a whole egg on the counter? The author convincingly traces the basis of time flow only forwards to the Big Bang and creation of high order and low entropy states in its immediate aftermath. Greene then introduces the reader to the most current ideas in cosmology - the stretching of space and time, inflationary expansion of the universe, the concept of the Higgs ocean and how mass arises. Is there one grand unified theory that connects the microcosmic world with the macrocosmic, asks Greene, and how does one reconcile the world of the quantum with the world of general relativity in cosmology? This is possible, he argues, in the domain of string theory & M-theory, which he explains with an artistic balance of the high science and the basic ideas behind the framework. Here the reader is introduced to a mind-numbing world of many dimensions, branes, time travel, and wormholes. Greene develops strings as the essence of the fundamental structure of everything as opposed to point particles, and shows how this resolves age-old problems in particle physics such as the infinite regress that one encounters in reconciling quantum ideas with relativity. Vibrating strings and quantum jitters lead to a more clear articulation of how three of the four forces we know (electromagnetic, strong force, and weak force) work within branes while gravity can work across branes, and hence may resolve some unexplainable paradoxes that we perceive. Greene offers easy to grasp analogies to help the reader grapple with a world of multiple dimensions, and makes this complex domain of the academic physicist comprehensible for the intellectually curious layperson to explore.The style in which this book is written makes it impossible to put down. This is a world of the fantastic, of travels to galaxies far, far away where one can depart from earth at light speed for a 6-hour round trip to say Andromeda, only to return back to an Earth that is many million years in the future. It is a world of quantum entanglement, where particles separated by enormous distances are in complete sync, and where the moon may not exist if you are not actually seeing it, even if you did see it only a moment ago. Reading this book will enlighten the reader as to why things are as they are, and to wonder "Are they, really?" This is a roller coaster ride that must not be passed up, one in which the mind whirls between ideas concerning worlds extremely small and large, in the tutelage of a master storyteller of the cosmos and the mysteries of our universe. What a wild ride this is, and what fun!

Subtitle: Space, Time, and the Texture of Reality. Which is a pretty big topic to fit into one book. Greene does a fairly good job of it, but it says something about his REAL topic, that he dare not put it into the title or subtitle. This is a book about String Theory, the physics theory which dare not speak its name.There's a lot in front of the string theory discussion. Greene delivers one of the more readable summaries (if something which takes about 300 pages can be called a 'summary') of classical, relativistic, and quantum physics. His particular angle in all of this is the nature of space and time, i.e. if the universe is like a painting, are they more like the canvas of a painting, or more like the frame?The problem which all of physics faces, however, is one which we have to face most directly when we look at string theory (or its rivals): physics has gotten ahead of the rest of us. We will need better math, or better software, or better engineering, or maybe even better philosophy before we can find a good way to test these things. Europe hopes to get around these inconvenient obstacles by simply throwing a bajillion euros at the problem and building a collider on the border of France and Switzerland big enough to detect strings, or lack of same, as the fundamental building blocks of the universe.If it happens, it will be nearly the only time string theory has come face to face with experimental evidence in decades since it was first proposed. Right now, it hangs in a weird limbo between science and speculation, much like the ether of 19th century physics, which turned out to be more or less a mass hallucination of the world physics community.Greene does his best to show that things aren't as grim as all of that. He reminds us of the context in which relativity and quantum physics were developed, and how they both were starved for experimental data for a time. But his history of physics also serves as an excellent reminder of how far off base even the sharpest minds can get when they don't have empirical evidence to right their course from time to time.This book is worth reading though, if only for the first several sections where he explains just how weird the (already well attested) theories of relativity and quantum physics are compared to our intuition. It helps that he sets many of his imaginary thought experiments in a town called Springfield, with characters named Bart, Lisa, Homer, Apu, etc. going through wormholes and traveling at nearly the speed of light. If relativity is the Simpsons' territory, quantum physics seems to be Mulder and Scully's, with Scully's skeptical (and Newtonian) view of the universe being constantly upended by Mulder's enthusiastic (and quantum) view. The Truth is Out There, and it's never been this easy to get somewhat of a handle on. String Theory's idea of eleven (or maybe twelve) dimensions is a bit harder to swallow, but give Greene credit, it's not for lack of a cogent and coherent explanation.Maybe, by a decade from now, that collider out in France and Switzerland will prove to us that string theory was all a blind alley, or maybe it will prove that it is the genuine Theory of Everything. Either way, Greene's book is still going to be worth reading, if only for a lighthearted look at some very heavy material about how we got here.

I like this book almost as much as I like "The Elegant Universe." However, there were a few things holding it back from a 5-star review.First, I read "The Elegant Universe" in the early 2000's (just a year or two after it was published). At that time all of Greene's forward-looking statements were very exciting. It made the cutting edge of physics seem much more like a spectators sport than it really is. Unfortunately, I somehow overlooked "The Fabric of the Cosmos" for 7 years and even though it contained a lot of ideas that were new to me it felt a bit dated. The Large Hadron Collider had not come online at the writing of "The Fabric of the Cosmos" and Greene talks a lot about what it might find (including things that have been discovered and made the news since).Perhaps because Greene's books might become dated he spends a good deal of time rehashing material he has already covered in his previous writings. Also, I suspect that for most people a ten year lapse between reading two of his books would necessitate a bit of a review. But, he did such a good job of explaining relativity and string-theory in "The Elegant Universe" that his explanations stuck in my head. So, this complaint should in no way dissuade you from reading his books.Finally, I got a little tired of being told I could skip bits. About half a dozen times in the last half of the book Greene tells the reader something to the effect of "The next bit is hard so you can skip it if you like." Was he worried people would put down the book and never pick it up if they encountered a bit of trouble understanding something? The first time I read a passage like that, it served as a challenge to me and I concentrated. By the third time, I started to feel like maybe he was encouraging me to find a different book. The whole point of Pop-Sci Books like this is to dumb-down things that only a few people in the world understand so that those people can share their excitement and their results with the rest of us. Telling your audience they can skip ahead because the next part didn't meet that goal shows a real lack of confidence. ;)Yikes, I just wrote four pretty critical paragraphs about a book that I really enjoyed. Here is a short list of the awesome stuff in this book (because if I keep writing no one will ever read this).1. There is a long passage about the idea that the universe might be a 3-Brane. This is very cool and also something I had not heard before (even though it does make an appearance on Wikipedia).2. The second half of the book has an explanation of the Higgs Field/Particle that since the writing of the book has been "discovered."3. An (light-on-details and thus very-understandable) explanation about how string-theory might be made independent of time and space. 4. There is a great explanation of how the "folded-up dimensions" that string-theory calls for could actually be bigger than the planck length without us noticing them. Anyway, I look forward to reading "The Hidden Reality" and will not wait a decade to do so.

The Fabric of the Cosmos: Space, Time, and the Texture of Reality "Every moment in time just is." That is a huge thing to wrap your mind around. Every moment in space-time just exists. While we experience the "arrow of time," the feeling of moving forward (which Greene explains) every moment already exists in the universe, and always will. When I saw an episode on NOVA made from this book I knew I had to read it. The episode I saw was "The Illusion of Time," and it blew me away. Watch it at the link and you'll be a 25-point Calvinist.Mathematics might be the highest form of worship; every Christian should read books such as this one about cosmology. The more we learn about the universe, the more improbable a self-existing first cause seems. As Greene points out, the universe we see now is dramatically less probable, statistically speaking, than one that developed from complete randomness. That the universe originated with a low-entropy (Big Bang) event is also highly improbable, but yet we know it happened.The universe started at a size smaller than the period on the end of this sentence. It had incredible symmetry, such that perhaps all of the forces we know today were combined together in one force. The laws of physics break down at that point, there's the incompatibility of quantum mechanics and generaly relativity such that we have a "fuzzy patch." But newly-discovered inflationary theory tells us much of what happens after the first moment, exactly how the universe began its incredible rapid expansion. (See Greene's recent article in Smithsonian Magazine).But, the "fuzzy patch still looks fuzzy."Galaxies are now moving apart from each other at high rates of speed. We discover planets and learn more about the makeup of the universe every day. The last third of the book deals with super string theory, which Greene also details more thoroughly in The Elegant Universe (some parts seem to be repeated verbatim in both works; I imagine all of his books essentially say the same things in different ways... one has to make money somehow).How many dimensions does space have? 10? More? Why did only 3 dimensions experience inflation after the Big Bang? What about curled dimensions? M theory? Planck length? Those are the tedium in the second half of the book. He does delve into the possibility of Star Trek-like teleportation, showing the recent advances in research that indicate this may one day be possible. Just this week the Army confirmed that it can teleport quantum data, for example.There is also an explanation of the theoretical and mathematical impossibilities of time travel-- traveling backwards in time. These are amusing aspects.Greene frequently uses Simpsons characters in his analogies. It is not nearly as analogic in language as The Elegant Universe, but it's mostly understandable. The second half of the book gets pretty heavy, though, an audio version is the only way I could get through it. When you get bogged down in quantum mechanics it helps to have the audio keep pushing you on to the main point.I really should not judge a book by one that followed it, but I give this book 3.5 stars out of 5.
